p:
Similar to conventional droughts, flash droughts occur with atmospheric conditions of positive geopotential height anomaly
15 and downward atmospheric motion at sub-seasonal time scales, but high evapotranspiration (ET) reduces soil moisture rapidly, and causes damage without sufficient early warning. Due to the intrinsic nature of extreme events
20, 21 and the uncertainty in simulating the hydrological cycle
22, 23 , detecting and attributing the human fingerprint (e.g., greenhouse gas emissions) on the changes of flash droughts at regional scale are therefore quite challenging. Moreover, projections of future changes are often carried out for droughts at seasonal, annual, or longer time scales
5, 6, 24 , while flash droughts occur at sub-seasonal time scale from a few weeks to months. The response of flash drought risk to greenhouse warming therefore remains unknown.
